content: The "After School Education and Anti-Crime Act of 1999" aims to improve academic and social outcomes for students, reduce juvenile crime, and prevent youth from becoming victims of crime by offering productive activities during after school hours. Congress finds that today's youth face increased social risks, spend more time unsupervised, and are most at risk of violence between 3 p.m. and 6 p.m. Academic failure consequences are more severe in 1999. After school programs are effective in addressing youth social problems, with many governors supporting their expansion through a Federal/State partnership. Over 450 police chiefs, sheriffs, and prosecutors, along with police officer associations, have urged public officials to provide after school programs for children and teens in the US, emphasizing the importance of safe and positive learning environments during those hours. The goals of this Act include increasing academic success, promoting safe after-school environments, providing alternatives to negative activities, and reducing juvenile crime. Section 10903 of the 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act is amended to provide support to local educational agencies for public schools serving communities with substantial needs for expanded learning opportunities for children and youth. Amendment to Section 10903 of the 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act includes changes to subsections (b) and (c), increasing the number from 3 to 5 in subsection (c) and adjusting language in subsection (b) for clarity. SEC. 6. APPLICATIONS. Section 10904 of the 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act is amended to redesignate subsections and make changes to the content requirements. The 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act is amended to include additional programs and stakeholders in paragraph (3). The 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act is amended to require local educational agencies to provide a minimum of 35% of project costs from non-federal sources and a maximum of 25% from funds provided by the Secretary. The local educational agency must ensure fiscal effort from non-Federal sources for activities funded under the project each year. SEC. 7. USES OF FUNDS. Section 10905 of the 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act is amended to allow grants for establishing or expanding community learning centers. The centers may offer activities including job skills preparation, mentoring programs, academic assistance, recreational activities, and technology training in after school programs. The 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act allows grants for establishing or expanding community learning centers, which may offer activities such as job skills preparation, mentoring programs, academic assistance, recreational activities, and technology training. Additionally, after school programs funded under this act must allocate at least two-thirds of the appropriated amount for activities like drug, alcohol, and gang prevention, health and nutrition counseling, and expanded opportunities for children or youth. The 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act allows grants for establishing or expanding community learning centers, which offer various activities. SEC. 8. ADMINISTRATION. Section 10905 of the 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act is amended to include provisions for local educational agencies or schools to involve volunteers from various communities, engage youth in designing activities, conduct outreach creatively, request donations, and collaborate with park and recreation departments. The 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act is amended to involve volunteers from communities, engage youth in designing activities, conduct outreach creatively, request donations, and collaborate with park and recreation agencies to avoid duplication of activities. SEC. 9 amends the 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act to include law enforcement organizations. SEC. 10 increases the authorization of appropriations to $600,000,000 for fiscal years 2000 through 2004. SEC. 11 states that the Act and its amendments take effect on October 1, 1999.
